Description: Fragment of wall of pottery pyxis. Clay light brown fairly clean; paint dull sepia-brown on outside, reddish and more glossy on inside. Slightly concave wall, flaring a little towards rim. On outside, rough painting, from top: three lines, six vertical stripes flanking a handle-stump(?) on left (surrounded by paint); three lines, zigzag, three lines; tops of row of elongated box/meander motifs. Two broad paint bands cover most of interior.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Hayes: "From Naukratis"? Apparently Boiotian Subgeometric, in which case too early to be a genuine Naukratis find. The discrepancy was first noted by J. Boardman (letter, August 1963). [Hayes 1992 p. 214 no. X25]
Bibliographic references: Hayes 1992 / Greek and Greek-Style Pottery and Plain Pottery in the Royal Ontario Museum; Excluding Black-Figure and Red-Figure Vases (p. 214 no. X25)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GS.181)
